components.text: This section will introduce the concept of disability, what to expect from employers and how to improve people's awareness of your disability

list_elements.text: To provide a clear definition of the concept of disability.
To inform students on what kind of reasonable adjustments to expect from employers.
To provide students with a general overview of how to make contact with staff and disclose their disability.
To support students to understand their rights and responsibilities with respect to disclosure.

components.text: You are classed as disabled under the Equality Act 2010 if you have a physical or mental impairment which has a ‘substantial’ and ‘long-term’ negative effect on your ability to do normal daily activities.

list_elements.text: 'substantial’ means the effect is more than minor or trivial, eg it takes much longer than it usually would to complete a daily task like getting dressed
‘long-term’ means the effect persist for 12 months or more, eg a breathing condition that develops as a result of a lung infection

components.text: A progressive condition is one that gets worse over time and people with progressive conditions can be classed as disabled.
However, you automatically meet the disability definition under the Equality Act 2010 from the day you’re diagnosed with HIV infection, cancer or multiple sclerosis.

myths.myth: It’s still ok to refer to people who do not have a disability as ‘able-bodied’?
myths.fact: No. This term suggests all disabilities are physical and that disabled employees or job applicants are not capable. Instead, if it is really necessary to make the distinction, use the term ‘non-disabled’ for people who do not have a disability.

myths.myth: To be disabled, the person has to be in a wheelchair, or blind, or lost a limb, something like that.
myths.fact: The definition of disability in the Equality Act 2010 is very broad and can cover a very wide range of conditions – what the law calls ‘impairments’. And some are not obvious – such as some mental health conditions.

components.text: Employers must make reasonable adjustments to ensure workers with disabilities, or physical or mental health conditions, aren’t substantially disadvantaged in their jobs. These adjustments may include:

list_elements.text: changing the recruitment process so a candidate can be considered for a job
doing things another way, such as allowing someone with social anxiety disorder to have their own desk instead of hot-desking
making physical changes to the workplace, such as installing a ramp for a wheelchair user or an audio-visual fire alarm for a deaf person
allowing  a disabled person to work somewhere else, such as on the ground floor for a wheelchair user
changing their equipment, for instance providing a special keyboard for a person with arthritis
allowing employees who become disabled to make a phased return to work, including flexible hours or part-time working
offering employees training opportunities, recreation and refreshment facilities

components.text: Reasonable adjustments apply to all employers and even should be considered for students whilst on placements.

The Disabilities team and the Mental Health team at the university have lots of experience working with students who have disabilities. Please feel free to contact them for advice with any concerns you may have relating to workplace and the reasonable adjustments you may be able to make for students with a disability, SpLD or Mental Health needs. Please note we can only give specific student related advice if a student has disclosed their learning needs to us (see Disclosure-Procedure) and completed a data protection form.

components.subtitle: Introduction to the Learning Support Team

components.text: It is the student’s choice to disclose their learning needs. For students who want to disclose, we recommend they do so at the earliest stage(on their application form) or contact the disabilities team. Disclosure means we can offer them support and advice and can discuss their needs and opportunities for adjustments with all those involved in their education.

It is an individual’s right not to disclose their learning need. If a student chooses not to disclose, we are unaware of their condition and any related difficulties, therefore we are unable to offer support or advice.

Students training to be health care professionals need to ensure they are able to work safely with patients and clients. Occupational Health can ascertain your fitness. Speak to your Learning Support Tutor ( LST ) or placement support tutor if you need any support.

components.text: This section will introduce the concept of disclosure and guidelines for disclosing a disability at the University.

list_elements.text: To provide a clear definition of the concept of disclosure.
To provide students with adequate guidelines and practical tips about how to disclose a disability.
To provide students with a step-by-step guide of how disclosure is evidenced and recorded at the University.
To support students understand their rights and responsibilities with respect to disclosure.

components.text: Disclosure is making a disability known to the university.  It involves discussing difficulties you may encounter, any reasonable adjustments needed for attainment and individual examination arrangements.

myths.myth: A job applicant has to tell an employer if they are disabled.
myths.fact: No. A disabled person can keep a disability confidential.

components.text: The following video clearly underlines how disclosing your disability can help staff and educators to support you during your placement, to provide the right reasonable adjustments and to make your experience enjoyable and satisfactory.

sections.subtitle: Deciding whether to disclose your disability

components.text: Deciding to disclose your disability to an employer is a matter of personal choice. You are under no legal obligation to do so, and it’s for you to choose if and when you disclose.  It is advisable to disclose, because once you’ve told an employer about your disability, you’re protected by the Equality Act 2010. This act protects individuals with Protected Characteristics from discrimination in the workplace. There are 9 Protected characteristics including disabilities (and long term health conditions such as a mental health condition), that may have substantial and long-term adverse effect on a person’s ability to carry out normal day-to-day activities

Think about whether your disability raises a health and safety issue for yourself or your future colleagues. If it does, you may have to disclose so that employers can help ensure you have a safe working environment. You may also wish to disclose if you need any adjustments to help accommodate your disability, either at the application stage or during your day-to-day work.

Once you’ve told an employer about your disability, you’re protected by the Equality Act 2010. This means your employer must take all reasonable steps to provide the necessary adjustments and mustn’t discriminate against you because of your disability.

Bear in mind that if you choose not to tell your employer and later underperform, you won’t be covered by the Equality Act. An employer who was unaware of your condition can’t be judged to have discriminated against you.

list_elements.text: There may be a section on the application form asking about any serious health conditions or disabilities. Although you don’t generally have to disclose your disability here, you mustn’t lie. If you don’t want to disclose, simply don’t answer the question. You can also use the personal statement section of the form to tell an employer about your disability.

There may be a gap in your educational history due to a period of prolonged illness. You can use your covering letter to explain this, but always present it in a way that will show you in a positive light. You can also refer to your disability in your CV if you attended a specialist school or college for disabled people.

If you mention your disability here, emphasise how it has further developed the skills and experience mentioned in your CV. However, only raise this when it’s relevant to your application. For example, point to how well you’ve achieved your goals despite any difficulties.

This is when you may want to identify practical needs so you can compete equally with other applicants. If you haven’t been asked about your needs, take the initiative and contact the employer in advance – they may need time to make arrangements.

You may feel more comfortable disclosing when you can discuss the implications face-to-face and more clearly demonstrate your skills. If you’ve previously mentioned your disability, the interview can be an opportunity to expand on any positive effects it’s had on your life and how it’s enhanced your employability.

You may decide to disclose your disability once you’ve been offered the job or when you start work. You can decide who to tell – your manager or HR – and you can also request that colleagues aren’t told. If your condition affects the way you work, it may be helpful to be open with colleagues so they understand and can help you with anything you may need.

Only discuss your disability in terms of its relevance to your performance in the job. Don’t go into personal detail. Always be positive about your disability and use it to provide evidence of the skills employers look for.

Emphasise positive achievements and give examples. You may have gained skills such as flexibility, determination, the ability to perform under pressure and creative problem-solving as a result of your disability, and you shouldn’t be afraid to use these as selling points.

Make a positive statement about your disability to remove any doubts an employer may have. Don’t assume they’ll have a negative attitude – your experiences and skills may give you the edge over other candidates.

Avoid focusing the whole of your application or interview on the issue of your disability. Your main focus should be on showing the employer your suitability for the job. Speak to a careers adviser about whether, when and how to tell an employer about your disability.

Some interviewers have little experience of disability and may feel unsure of workplace implications. Be prepared to make suggestions about what adjustments you would need in order to do the job effectively

sections.subtitle: For support with disclosing your disability

components.text: Employability Support can advise students on how and when to make a disclosure. We can help student to present information to employers in a positive, responsible and professional manner.  Employability Support also works with employers to help them to make adjustments and prepare to take a student with disability on placement. For further information contact Employability Support.
You can disclose at any time during the recruitment process, such as on your application or UCAS form, or when you are on your course.
You can also disclose a disability through contacting the Disabilities Team using Connect2 or emailing:
An appointment with a Disability Advisor can be made by following the link:
https://healthandwellbeingbookings.coventry.ac.uk/
You can also make appointments or contact the Disabilities Team through the student portal and selecting ‘support at CU’.
Documents that will need to be provided and completed are:

list_elements.text: Evidence of your disability
Completion of Individual Examination Arrangement (IEA) form for courses with exams

components.subtitle: Link to Document
components.text: Document

Evidence of a disability is either medical evidence or a diagnostic report. If you have a specific learning difficulty (SpLD), such as dyslexia, you will need to provide a copy of your diagnostic report.

If you have a medical condition, you will need to provide evidence of your condition. This may be a doctor’s letter, copy of medical records or a medical report. The evidence should outline how your disability impacts upon your daily activities.

If you have a medical condition, you will need to provide evidence including a doctor’s letter, copy of medical records or a medical report. If you have an autism spectrum condition, you will need to provide a copy of an educational psychologist's report or doctors letter.
All evidence should outline how your disability impacts upon your daily activities.

Provide your evidence to the Disabilities Team, either by email or by visiting the Disabilities Team on the 2nd floor of the Hub. Once you have provided your diagnostic evidence, the disabilities department will verify your disability on Universe.

sections.subtitle: How to sign the Data Protection Form

components.text: The data protection form should be signed as soon as possible once you have made contact with the Disabilities Team. It can be completed electronically (by emailing and scanning your copy), during an appointment or you can visit the department. These forms allow staff to communicate with other members of staff to organise adjustments, exam arrangements, funding (where applicable) and care for other needs if needed.

components.subtitle: Without your signature we cannot take action!
components.text: These forms allow staff to communicate with other members of staff to organise adjustments, exam arrangements, funding (where applicable) and care for other needs if needed.

sections.subtitle: Make your department aware of your disability

components.text: You should tell your department directly about your disability, which can be done through email or "face-to-face" conversations. Your department can also look on Solar which contains information about disability details, exam arrangements and reasonable adjustments.

The University has a legal obligation to support to keep all sensitive information about students’ confidential adhering to data protection laws. When a student provides information about a disability, condition, or other medical needs it will be treated with strict confidentiality. The University has policies in place to ensure data is protected reasonably and confidentiality maintained. 
The Disability Team will hold all data students provide about their disability and you can decide who you need to share this information with. To discuss reasonable adjustments on placements, you will need share the information with teams and people on a “need to know” bases for example - the placement team, the learning support tutor and the placement teams. You are not obliged to share the information. If you share the information, you will be supported by the various support teams and you will sign a disability disclosure agreement.

sections.subtitle: How information submitted to the Disability Team is stored

list_elements.text: Information held by the Disability Team about students will be held for 6 years in accordance with the Data Protection Act (1998). It is then disposed of securely.

All written records and files containing students' confidential details will be kept in a secure and locked environment. Student details are kept electronically on the secure databases. The records are accessible to authorised University staff. Under the Data Protection Act (1998) students have the right to access their own records.
Statistical information gathered for research, evaluation or monitoring purposes will be anonymous.

sections.subtitle: Speaking to your personal tutor and LST

components.text: All Faculties and Departments have an allocated Learning Support Tutor. Contact your learning Support tutor for information and support about preparing for placements and any challenges you may have.

questions.text: Disclosure involves taking responsibility to make your disability known to the university through completing the admissions form or by discussing your disability with the Disabilities Team.
The university can verify your disability when you talk to them about your needs.
questions.tip: the university can verify your disability after you have supplied diagnostic evidence.

questions.text: Evidence is only required for a medical condition.
questions.tip: evidence is required for all disabilities including Specific Learning Disabilities (e.g. dyslexia, dyspraxia etc.)

questions.text: It is your responsibility to verify your disability.
questions.tip: The Disability Team will verify your disability once they have received diagnostic evidence.  It is your responsibility to disclose and provide evidence in the first instance.

questions.text: The data protection form should be signed at the earliest point.
Once your disability is verified by the disabilities Team, all adjustments etc. will be put in place.
questions.tip: It is useful and important for you to speak directly to your faculty and ensure they are aware of; your disability, reasonable adjustments requested and other needs (e.g. IEA).

questions.text: If details of your disability are added and saved on the University’s database all arrangements/ adjustments will be organised.
questions.tip: Whilst having the details added to the database is necessary it is not a guarantee that everything will run smoothly. It is useful for you to regularly communicate with your faculty to ensure they are aware of; your disability, reasonable adjustments requested and other needs (e.g. IEA and placement requests).

list_elements.text: Discuss the challenges of teaching and learning in a practice setting
Understand the Equality Act and what it means for the disabled student
Appreciate the need for reasonable adjustments and how they support students with a disability
Understand the support systems and mechanisms of support systems, students with disabilities can access

components.text: Learning in practice is usually unpredictable because it involves structuring a learning environment in a work place that is dynamic, challenging and sometimes, stressful. Students and educators/mentors share responsibility for learning. The educator/mentor is tasked with creating learning opportunities for the students as part of their primary role of delivering effective healthcare. The student is expected to have developed the theoretical knowledge necessary to engage with the learning and take responsibility for speaking to the educator about what is within their scope of practice. The complexity of challenging the student appropriately and supporting different learning styles is compounded by the workload.
Learning in clinical practice is challenging regarding organizational and pedagogical issues
components.author: Manninen

components.text: The following link contains several videos where students share their placement experience. Watch them to get a better understanding about what your expectations should be.
Student on Placement Experiences

Many students may not have practical experience so have questions and concerns; being on placement can be significantly different to academic assignments. You are not alone; frequently asked questions and concerns include:

list_elements.text: How do I complete my placement documentation?

What if I don’t like my placement?

components.text: You can direct questions to your personal tutor, learning support tutor or course leader well before the placement begins.

components.subtitle: Disabilities Team
components.text: You can also contact the Disabilities Team. They have lots of experience working with students who have disabilities and are happy to provide you with advice, tips and will support you with your concerns.

sections.subtitle: Challenges of learning in practice settings

list_elements.text: The practice environment is primarily about meeting the needs of patients and ensuring clinical practice is safe and professional. Students are in the practice setting to learn, however, their education is a secondary feature of the learning environment. The educator/mentor will be doing their job and at the same time maximising opportunities to ensure students learn.

Students have the advantage of engaging with educators/mentors who are modelling professional thinking, behaviour, and attitudes. Students also have the opportunity to practice in real time, clinical skills of history taking, physical examination, clinical reasoning, decision making, empathy, and professionalism.

The students and educator/mentors will need to negotiate all the challenges associated with teaching in such an unfriendly teaching environment. This means communicating, being responsive, prepared theoretically and professionally to work with your educator/mentor.

Set appropriate goals with your educator at the beginning of the placement.
Discuss how you will work together to achieve the goals with respect to time pressure, patient safety and any needs you may have.

components.subtitle: The top ten myths about disability in the workplace -ACAS

myths.myth: If a problem arises about an employee’s disability, it is likely to turn into a dispute which will go on for a long time.
myths.fact: Not necessarily. Often, the best option is for the employer to have a quiet word with those involved to reach a resolution early and to which they can all agree.

myths.myth: A disabled employee is unlikely to contribute as much as a non-disabled employee.
myths.fact: Employers often complain of a skills shortage yet at the same time overlook a pool of talent. There are currently over three million disabled people in work, but nearly five million disabled people of working age are not – a huge source of potential talent.

myths.myth: In redundancy, an employer has to create a vacancy for a disabled employee.
myths.fact: No. An employer doesn’t always have to redeploy disabled employees. They should be capable and qualified for any new job, with any ‘reasonable adjustments’ in place.

sections.subtitle: The Heath Care Professions Council and Nursing and Midwifery Council Competencies and guidance

components.subtitle: HCPC Guidance on conduct and ethics for students

sections.subtitle: 1. Promote and protect the interests of service users and carers

list_elements.text: You should treat service users and carers as individuals, respecting their privacy and dignity.
You should make sure that you have consent from service users or other appropriate authority before you provide any care, treatment or other services.
You should follow your education provider's or practice placement provider's policy on consent.
You should make sure that before you provide any care, treatment or other services, the service user is aware that you are a student.
You should respect a person's right to have their care, treatment or other services carried out by a professional and not a student.
You should treat everyone equally and not discriminate against anyone because of your personal views.
You should keep relationships with service users and carers professional.
You should be polite and considerate to service users, other students and staff at your education provider and practice placement provider.
You should listen to service users and carers and take account of their needs and wishes when carrying out any care, treatment or other services.
You should take all reasonable steps to make sure that you can communicate appropriately and effectively with service users and carers.
You should communicate effectively and co-operate with members of staff at your education provider and practice placement provider to benefit service users and carers.

If you are experiencing any difficulties or other issues which may affect your learning or ability to successfully participate in your programme, you should tell your education provider and practice placement provider.
You should use all forms of communication appropriately and responsibly, including social media and networking websites.

sections.subtitle: 3. Work within the limits of your knowledge and skills

list_elements.text: You should make sure that you are appropriately supervised for any task that you are asked to carry out.
You should ask for help when you need it.
You should be aware of any restrictions which apply to you in carrying out certain tasks and follow any relevant policies of your education provider or practice placement provider.
You should recognise that opportunities for carrying out any unsupervised tasks will vary during your programme and may depend on your knowledge, understanding, skills and experience.
You should only carry out an unsupervised task if you feel that you have the appropriate knowledge and skills to do so safely and effectively.
You should take responsibility for your own learning.
You should be aware of and follow any guidance issued by your education provider or practice placement provider for working with service users and carers.
You should ask for, listen to, think about and respond proactively to feedback you are given.
You should recognise that the opportunities for delegation will vary during your programme depending on your knowledge, understanding, skills and experience.
You should discuss the delegation of tasks with an appropriate member of staff at your education provider or practice placement provider before you take any action.
You should follow local policies or guidelines on delegation and working with others produced by your education provider or practice placement provider.

If you give tasks to another person to carry out on your behalf, you should make sure that they have the knowledge, skills and experience to carry out the tasks safely and effectively. The education provider or practice placement provider should support your decision to delegate.
If you give tasks to another person to carry out on your behalf, you should make sure that they have the appropriate information to carry out the tasks safely and effectively.
You should explain to service users and carers when you have asked another person to provide any care, treatment or other services
You should keep information about service users and carers confidential, and only use it for the purpose for which it was given.
You should follow local policies or guidelines on confidentiality produced by your education provider or practice placement provider.
You should remove anything that could be used to identify a service user or carer from information which you use in your assessments or other academic work related to your programme.

If any confidential information raises concerns about the safety or wellbeing of someone, you should discuss this promptly with an appropriate member of staff at your education provider or practice placement provider.
You should make sure that you take all appropriate steps to limit the risk of harm to service users, carers and others.
You should not do anything that you think will put someone in danger or at unacceptable risk.
You should follow your education provider's or practice placement provider's policy on managing risk.
You should be aware that you may put your service users or yourself at risk if your performance or judgement is affected by your physical or mental health.

You should ask for appropriate support and adapt your study or stop studying if your performance or judgement is affected by your physical or mental health and could put service users, yourself or others at risk.
You should get advice from a doctor or other appropriate professional if you are worried about your physical or mental health.

If you are worried about the safety or wellbeing of service users, carers or others, you should speak to an appropriate member of staff at your education provider or practice placement provider promptly.

You should put the safety and wellbeing of service users before any personal concerns, for example, about assessments, marks, other work related to your programme, employment prospects or other personal gain.

sections.subtitle: 8.  Be open when things go wrong

list_elements.text: You should tell an appropriate member of staff at your education provider or practice placement provider if something has gone wrong in any care, treatment or other services you have carried out involving a service user.

You should co-operate with members of staff at your education provider and practice placement provider if something has gone wrong in any care, treatment or other services you have carried out involving a service user. You should learn from this experience.

You should tell an appropriate member of staff at your education provider or practice placement provider if a service user or carer wants to raise concerns about any care, treatment or other services they have received.
You should make sure that your conduct and behaviour does not damage public trust and confidence in your profession.
You should be aware that your conduct and behaviour outside of your programme may affect whether or not you are allowed to complete your programme or register with us.
You should not claim that you have knowledge, skills, qualifications and experience which you do not.
You should be honest about your role with service users, carers and others.
You should make sure that your personal appearance is appropriate for your practice placement environment.
You should follow your education provider's or practice placement provider's policy on attendance.
You should follow your education provider's policies on ethics when carrying out research.
You should make sure that all attendance, achievement and assessment records are completed accurately and truthfully.
You should reference other people's work appropriately and not pass it off as your own.
You should provide constructive feedback on the quality of your teaching and learning experience in both the education and practice placement setting.
You should provide, as soon as possible, any important information about your conduct, competence or health to your education provider and practice placement provider.
You should tell your education provider, as soon as possible, if you are charged with, convicted of, or accept a caution for, any offence.
You should co-operate with any investigation into your conduct or competence.

sections.subtitle: 10.  Keep records of your work with service users and carers

list_elements.text: You should make sure that the records you keep are clear and accurate.
You should help to protect records from being damaged, lost or accessed by someone without permission.
You should follow your education provider's or practice placement provider's policy on record keeping.

sections.subtitle: Becoming a Health and Care Professional

components.text: The Equality Act was introduced to simplify and strengthen discrimination laws across Britain. It harmonised 116 pieces of legislation. The aim of the legislation is to protect certain categories of people from unfair treatment.

components.subtitle: What is a disability under the Equality Act

list_elements.text: Age
Disability
Gender reassignment
Marriage and civil partnership
Race
Religion or belief
Sex
Sexual Orientation

components.subtitle: Direct discrimination
components.text: An individual or organisation that provides services to the public must not treat someone worse just because of one or more protected characteristics…

components.subtitle: Indirect discrimination
components.text: An organisation must not do something to someone in a way that has a worse impact on them and other people who share a particular protected characteristic than it has on people who do not share that characteristic. Unless the organisation can show that what they have done is objectively justified…

components.subtitle: Discrimination arising from disability
components.text: Service providers must not treat disabled people unfavourably because of something connected to their disability where they cannot show that what they are doing is objectively justified. This only applies if the individual or organisation knows, or could reasonably have been expected to know, that the person is disabled
A good summary of the Equality Act can be found at the link below:
The Equality Act allows for discrimination against any of the protected characteristics.

The Equality Act says discrimination can be justified if the person who's discriminating against you can show it’s a proportionate means of achieving a legitimate aim. If necessary, it's the courts which will decide if discrimination can be justified
components.author: Citizen’s advice website

components.text: A legitimate aim is the reason behind the discrimination. This reason must not be discriminatory in itself and it must be a genuine or real reason.
Here are some examples of legitimate aims:

list_elements.text: the health, safety and welfare of individuals
running an efficient service
requirements of a business
desire to make profit

components.text: Health and social care training programmes need to ensure that potential registrants are capable of meeting the competencies set out in the regulatory guidelines and can support the delivery of an efficient service.
The following link points to a document that contains valuable information regarding the understanding of the Equality Act.

myths.myth: Once an employer has hired a disabled person, they can’t sack them.
myths.fact: An employer can dismiss a disabled employee if the dismissal is justified and they have taken all the correct steps.

myths.myth: Nobody thinks in stereotypes – we’re more sophisticated now.
myths.fact: In 2015, it was reported that 42% of disabled people seeking work found the biggest barrier to getting hired were misconceptions around what they could do.

components.text: Equality law identifies disabled people as one of eight protected categories in society. This means that the way society organises education, employment and access to recreation, etc. needs to be restructured to account for any barriers that may treat people with disabilities unfairly. In higher education, the law states it is the duty of institutions to provide students with disabilities reasonable adjustments.

components.subtitle: What is it?
components.text: Reasonable adjustments are very simply any alterations that need to be made to ensure a disabled person is not disadvantaged. However, the changes have to be considered reasonable. There are certain considerations that could be made when deciding if something is “reasonable”:
For example:

list_elements.text: How effective the adjustments will be in reducing/elminating the disadvantage the disabled worker would otherwise experience
Its practicality
Its cost
Your organisation’s resources and size
The availability of financial support.(GOV.UK website)

components.text: The link below will take you to the Disability Rights website which has a very detailed list of all the reasonable adjustments you should expect from employers.

components.subtitle: Reasonable Adjustments under the Equality Act

myths.myth: It will be expensive for an employer to hire a disabled person.
myths.fact: Most ‘ reasonable adjustments’ cost nothing or very little.  Only 4% of them do cost  (and even then the average is £184 per disabled employee) and the emphasis is on the word ‘reasonable and what is reasonable can depend on the size of the business.

components.text: Learning in practice is structurally different to learning in the classroom. Students are entitled to support from their educators and could have access to reasonable adjustments, provided they can meet the competencies set out in the standards of proficiency.

components.text: Many students may not have practical experience so have questions and concerns; being on placement can be significantly different to academic assignments. Frequently asked questions and concerns include:

list_elements.text: How do I complete my placement documentation?

components.text: If you are worried about completing any official documents speak to your Academic Personal Tutor, Learning Support Tutor or contact the Disability team for support.

list_elements.text: Who will I talk to about any issues once on placement?

components.text: Your educator will be willing to address any concerns you may have, also you could contact the visiting tutor or the disability team on campus.

list_elements.text: How will I meet all the competencies?

components.text: If you are worried about your ability to meet any competencies, speak to your Learning Support tutor.

list_elements.text: What if I don’t like my placement?

components.text: Have an open mind and a positive attitude towards the placement, try to assess objectively what you may not like. You may find the work and learning on placement challenging but if you find you do not like working in that environment you may want to consider why you chose the profession. Speak to your academic tutor or contact the disability team on campus to arrange an appointment.

list_elements.text: How do I manage assignments and placement commitments/shifts?

components.text: You will be given a typical shift, this will basically correspond to the type of shifts you should expect when you qualify. There are absence policies in the hand books, if you are unable to make a shift, it is expected that you inform your educator and all relevant personnel in a professional manner.

list_elements.text: Good time keeping

components.text: You are expected to be on time and present throughout the placement period. If you have challenges getting to and from the placement, let your educator or mentor know your travel arrangements, they may be able to advise you about alternate routes or more suitable public transport links. Always plan to arrive at work 15 – 30 minutes before your shift begins and consider heavy traffic, parking problems and delays around hospitals.

list_elements.text: Finances

components.text: It will be a good opportunity to review your finances, ensure you have enough money saved as you may not be able to work during a placement. Some students save up for placements during the summer, ensuring they have the extra cash to cover any moving costs or transportation. Make a list of all the things you need and have a sensible financial plan ready. Note that student bursaries are no longer available for the majority of health and social care students in England. Some students with disabilities may be able to get some financial help, see 1 and 2 for further information.

list_elements.text: Feeling isolated

components.text: Having peers on the same placement is good practice. It is important you plan to have a normal social life while you are on placement.

Your placement will have various requirements for you to meet. It is useful to be aware of these requirements through reading your placement handbook and the competencies. Direct any questions about these requirements to your personal tutor, learning support tutor or course leader before the placement begins. Having understanding before starting will help you feel prepared and ready.

The following is a short animation to remind you that you are not alone during your placement and when preparing. The disabilities team is just a phone call away and you should not hesitate to contact if needed
If you have any questions during placement you can contact the disabilities team by phone or email:
The disabilities team has lots of experience working with students who have disabilities. They are happy to provide you with advice, tips and will support you with your concerns.
Disabled Students Allowances (DSAs) - This is funding that can be applied for to give disabled students the extra financial support they require whilst studying.
An individual may be entitled to apply for DSA if the student has:
components.subtitle: Eligibility

list_elements.text: A disability
A specific learning difficulty – like dyslexia
An on-going health condition
A mental-health condition.

components.text: The University disability and wellbeing team can help you if you understand the eligibility criteria and how to apply.

sections.subtitle: How to get a Disabled Students Allowance (DSA)

components.text: DSAs are awarded in the form of a grant, not repayable, and can be applied for on their own or as additional funding on top of the standard student finance you are entitled to. Book an appointment to talk to someone about your concerns:
DSA helps pay for things like:

list_elements.text: Equipment, i.e. computer hardware and software,
Travel costs towards the extras you have to pay as a result of your disability
Books and stationery, i.e. books in Braille or large print
Non-medical help, i.e. a note-taker to assist you during lectures

components.text: Funding is dependent on your needs. To determine the financial support a student may be offered a ‘needs assessment’ is required. A disabled student will have a discussion with an assessor who recommends to a funding body what may be needed. The funding body will then decide if they want to approve the support.
For example the DSA website explains:

You may be recommended a new computer if your current computer does not meet the required specification or you do not have one. If you are applying for DSAs for the first time you will be required to pay a personal contribution of £200 towards the cost of any computer.

Speak to your Learning Support Tutor (LST) and a tutor in the disability about your needs before you go for the needs assessment. You will want to discuss any needs you may require whilst on placement.

links.text: Further information from the DSA about a needs assessment
Useful Information for the 2017/2018 Academic Year

components.text: To ensure your DSA is in place for you as quickly as possible, follow these top tips:

list_elements.text: Apply as early as possible – in most cases, you don’t need to have a place confirmed at university or college to apply
Once you receive notification that you are eligible, book your needs assessment as soon as you can

When you attend your needs assessment interview, in addition to the medical evidence returned to the centre, you should give the assessor as much information as possible. You may want to take along any other relevant paperwork you have to help the assessor with determining what will help you
As soon as you receive your entitlement notification from your funding body, you should contact the authorised supplier the agreed support and equipment

components.text: There are many myths about placements. Some students are worried about working in non-campus setting and being introduced to the world of work. But placements are learning environments too. Students have to acknowledge that the learning is taking place in a “real world” clinical health delivery space, as such the rules of engagement are different. Ensure you clearly understand the purpose of your placement, what you want to achieve and the level of your commitment. Do your best to learn as much as you can and demonstrate to show educators and mentors that you are dedicated student who has a lot to learn. The educators and mentors would like to know your scope of practice and will be happy to help you when you make mistakes

sections.subtitle: Receiving Support from Disabilities Support Team

components.subtitle: The Disabilities Team
components.text: The disabilities team can support you through offering advice, tips and through teaching study skills to contribute to success whilst on placement e.g. strategies to learn and remember new vocabulary.

If you have any questions about preparing for your placement and would like some tips and advice from the disability advisors or specialist tutors, you can book an appointment with the disabilities team. To book an appointment, follow the link below:

Reasonable adjustments are changes to the work environment that allow people with disability to work safely and productively. Under the Equal Opportunity Act 2010, 'disability' includes: physical, psychological or neurological disease/disorder and illnesses, whether temporary or permanent.
The link above represents a website published for Australian audiences, however it contains information relevant to UK students.
A student with a disability can legally request Reasonable Adjustments(RA) when they are going on placement. You will be supported by the Learning Support Tutor to put these in place.
It is your responsibility to think about what you will need and articulate these clearly to the placement.
You can get help on this from the Learning Support Tutor and the Disability Office.
If you have a disability that will have an impact on your work or behaviour ensure you inform the relevant people prior to the placement.
If you require support or additional needs, you will need to inform your educator. It is better you do this before the placement.

components.text: It’s just a placement – like a different kind of classroom. Make sure you have a positive attitude, the motivation to do well, a good support system and the theoretical knowledge you need. If you need to read up, ask your educator which areas are most relevant to the area you will be focusing on.

components.text: If you have a disability that will have an impact on your work or behaviour ensure you inform the relevant people prior to the placement. Follow the link below to see a flowchart that may help you find out which people you have to inform.
If you require support or additional needs, you will need to inform your educator. It is better you do this before the placement.

sections.subtitle: Now what? Consider what you will need

list_elements.text: How will you get to and from work? Look up transport links and plan for possible delays or cancellations if you are using public transport. Ask about parking and possible tips from your educator or other staff.
Do you know the shifts you will be working?
Ensure you are meeting the requirements and competencies. You can break them down into SMART goals.
Small, measurable, achievable, relevant and timebound
Your educator needs your feedback to support you. Listen carefully to what the educator/mentor wants you to achieve and feel free to discuss your scope of practice and how you learn best.
You can always ask for support. If you feel you need support contact the disability team, your learning support tutor or your educator/mentor.

sections.subtitle: What if I think of something after?

components.text: It is OK if you think of any questions after you’ve made pre-placement contact, after you’ve completed documentation or after you’ve met with support staff.

list_elements.text: If you have questions you can contact your Learning Support Tutor(LST) by email.
You could also make further contact with your practice educator by phone or make second pre-placement contact.

components.text: For further tips and advice, make an appointment or email the disabilities team:

sections.subtitle: Discuss with private tutor or learning support tutor about pre placement contact

components.text: It is your responsibility as a student to contact the placement before you begin. If you need time to discuss any reasonable adjustments, you could ask the LST to support you.

Educators and mentors are usually busy doing their day job; however, they will be happy to discuss your learning needs with you. You could decide if you want to visit the placement before you begin or make contact via telephone.

sections.subtitle: When should you know about your placement

components.text: You will be informed about your placement 2- 4 weeks before you start. In very rare cases, there may be a delay, but the placement team will keep you informed. You will be supported by the LST and placement team if you ask for help and communicate your concerns.
It is good practice to contact the placement before you start. You can do this by telephone or arrange a pre placement visit.

Many placement sites are busy environments and it may be difficult to arrange a pre placement visit. If you will benefit from a preplacement visit, ensure you arrange this in good time so that the team has time to arrange it and have a brief chat with you. A pre placement visit does not have to be long. Do your best to make a list of what you want to say and be as concise and clear as possible.
Try to articulate what you may need to have a successful Placement
You could ask a disability tutor to help you articulate your thoughts.

sections.subtitle: If you cannot arrange a preplacement visit

components.text: You can make a list of your needs and goals and give this to your educator when you begin your placement and have your first meeting to discuss the placement
Do you need a real time visit or a telephone call?

If you need reasonable adjustments make sure they are all agreed and documented. If you are unclear about anything, you could speak to the LST about what has been agreed. Watch the videos at the following link to get a better idea about what additional needs means.

links.text: CSP -Top tips for clinical placement success

components.text: Reasonable adjustments are changes to the work environment that allow people with disability to work safely and productively. Under the Equal Opportunity Act 2010, 'disability' includes: physical, psychological or neurological disease or disorder. illness, whether temporary or permanent.

links.text: About reasonable adjustments ( Australia, but still relevant)

components.text: A student with a disability can legally request RA when they are going on placement. You will be supported by the Learning Support Tutor to put these in place.
It is your responsibility to think about what you will need and articulate these clearly to the placement.
You can get help on this from the Learning Support Tutor and the Disability Office
If you have any questions during placement you can contact the disabilities team by phone or email:
The disabilities team has lots of experience working with students who have disabilities. They are happy to provide you with advice, tips and will support you with your concerns.
Use this checklist to break down you pre-placement period into sub-tasks that are easier to complete and keep track of.
What do you feel will make you less concerned about your placement?
Most placements are successful. Do you have everything you need to succeed?

It is important you have all the information you need before your placement. There are a lot of resources to enable you plan and prepare adequately for your placement. Most placements are successful, as such the likelihood that you will have an unsuccessful placement is slim.
Ensure you have everything you need so you can be confident you will be at your best when you arrive at the placement.

components.text: Every student will benefit from considering the coping strategies they could use on placement. You may feel a little drained, physically or emotionally worn down and/or find working with certain people difficult. The work place is challenging and you may encounter people or situations that knock your confidence or demand a lot from your emotional reservoir.
This section will highlight some key tips for coping on placement and suggestions for planning towards a successful placement.

As a student you are ultimately responsible for your learning. You will have a lot of support from your tutors at University who have prepared you theoretically for practicing skills, values and attitudes during the placement. Educators and mentors will be supporting you during the placement by providing learning opportunities and giving you feedback. The educators and mentors will also be your assessors and therefore will be responsible for ensuring that you can demonstrate the competencies and practice safely.

As a student it is important you understand the outcomes for each placement, ensure you understand what you need to demonstrate and take any opportunities for learning seriously. Do what you can to learn and show your educator or mentor that you are meeting the required competencies.
You will be able to discuss any concerns with your educator or mentor.

sections.subtitle: Getting the most out of your Clinical Placement

components.subtitle: Key Points to follow in order to get the most out of your placement

components.text: 1.   There are usually a lot of students on placement at any given time. Students are on placement often during the training period.
2.   Educators are trained, registered and supported. Mentors must be a registered nurse with at least 12 months’ experience and a mentoring qualification
3.   Although students are expected to participate in direct patient care, they remain supernumerary
4.   Students should be encouraged to reflect as this helps to link theory learnt in university to experiences gained in practice
5.   Students have a responsibility to report behaviour that puts others at risk

components.subtitle: Follow this link for more information

links.text: Getting the most out of your placement

links.text: Get Back to where we belong Guide for disabled people in employment
Helping students get the best from their practice placements.

links.link: pdfs/Resilience booklet going wth the flow for TFL employees.pdf
links.text: Resilience booklet going wth the flow for TFL employees

components.text: The best thing you could take on placement is a positive attitude. Educators and mentors are always happy to welcome students and support their learning. They find this easier when students come to the placement with an attitude that is positive. This simply means a student is willing to learn and will be confident to ask for help when they are confronted by activities that are outside their scope of practice. The clinical placement is not a natural pedagogical atmosphere, however, the educators and mentors have been in your shoes and are quite welcoming and inspiring. You are quite likely to find new graduates on your ward who were on placement just a few months ago too; they will be happy to support your learning and help you.
Student nurses value a welcoming workplace where staff and educators are happy to help and have a positive attitude to student presence on the wards
components.author: Doyle et al

components.text: Your health is very important. Wellbeing involves taking care of emotional and mental wellbeing as well as physical wellbeing.
If you are feeling unwell, physically or mentally, you should always seek the opinion of a doctor.

Physical health is connected to mental and emotional health. Taking care of your body is an effective first step towards mental and emotional health. The mind and the body are linked and health benefits of becoming more physically active are significant. Physical activity involves anything we do that involves moving our bodies including exercise and sport.

components.subtitle: How can I increase my physical activity?

list_elements.text: Set specific, realistic and attainable goals
Take the stairs instead of the lift/ elevator
Visit Coventry University’s sport centre and take a class or visit the gym
Add short walks in between lectures/ study sessions
Become involved in a sport
Start using a pedometer to track your walking

components.text: When you improve your physical health, you'll experience greater mental and emotional well-being

components.subtitle: The key to a healthy diet is to:
components.text:
Eat the right amount of calories for how active you are, so that you balance the energy you consume with the energy you use. If you eat or drink too much, you'll put on weight. If you eat and drink too little, you'll lose weight.

Eat a wide range of foods to ensure that you're getting a balanced diet and that your body is receiving all the nutrients it needs.

components.subtitle: These eight practical tips cover the basics of healthy eating, and can help you make healthier choices

list_elements.text: Base your meals on starchy carbohydrates
Eat lots of fruits and vegetables.
Eat more fish - including a portion of oily fish - or include vegetarian sources of omega 3.
Cut down on saturated fat and sugar.
Eat less salt - no more than 6g a day for adults.
Get active and have a healthy weight.
Don't get thirsty.
Don't skip breakfast.

links.text: NHS - Eight tips to staying healthy

components.text: Mental wellbeing describes your mental state - how you are feeling and how well you can cope with day-to-day life.

components.subtitle: Five steps to mental wellbeing are:

list_elements.text: Connect and communicate face to face with people – there is strong evidence that suggests that feeling close to and valued by other people is a fundamental human need.
Be active – regular physical activity is linked to lower rates of depression and anxiety
Take notice – reminding yourself to take notice can strengthen and broaden awareness. Take time to enjoy the environment around you.
Learn – continuing to learn throughout life builds good self-esteem and encourages social interaction.
Give – individuals who report a greater interest in helping others are more likely to rate themselves as feeling happy.

links.text: NHS - Adult Improving Access to Psychological Therapies programme (IAPT)
Counselling Directory - find a counsellor near you

sections.subtitle: What to do if you feel isolated

components.text: Some students report feelings of isolation on their placement. This may be because they are away from their friends and home. Don’t worry- there are lots of strategies you can use to reduce these feelings.

list_elements.text: Friends
The Disabilities Team
Family
Your mentor or practice educator
Enquire about other students on placement near you
Get involved in activities organised by your placement
Keep in touch using social media
Plan activities for your days off

components.text: If these feelings persist you may need to book an appointment to visit your GP.

components.subtitle: Working in a professional work environment
components.text: Research the Trust, school or organisation you will be working in. You can learn about the ethos and culture by looking on the internet. You will benefit from learning as much as you can about the local policies, the community of professionals and the work practice. You could ask your educator/mentor questions about policies you do not understand during your induction.

Before you start a placement reflect on what your strengths are and how you could use this to your advantage during placement. You may be good communicator or great at organising and managing your time. These are great skills. You could also think about the things you may struggle with and what you can do to.
components.subtitle: What are your challenges?

videos.subtitle: Student nurses give their advice about placement

components.text: The patient is at the centre of healthcare delivery. Everything that happens in a clinical or work environment centres on supporting patient care. Students on placement are expected to ensure they are fit to participate in this duty and are not at risk to patients in anyway.

components.subtitle: Nursing students talk about their experiences
Be flexible
components.text: The clinical environment is unlike any other workplace. Be prepared to be flexible. No two days would be the same. It is an exciting opportunity to experience and learn all you can about your profession and see first-hand how you would be expected to behave and practice when you qualify.

Be prepared to enjoy the ride, unexpected things may happen, you will be thinking on your feet and responding to some very challenging situations. You have all the support you will need and you are not expected to act a registered member of staff, so you have the opportunity to ask a lot of questions and reflect on your experiences. Perhaps it may be useful to keep a reflective diary.
The Student Executive Committee (Chartered Physiotherapy Society) have a few tips to help you get the most from the experience.

list_elements.text: What to expect – Placements are work environments, primarily geared towards caring for patients or clients. It is an opportunity to learn skills and good practice.
Your responsibilities and Professional etiquette and personal conduct  – See guidelines from HCPC and NMC
Your host’s responsibilities – the placement providers are expected to support your learning and assess your skills. They have a duty of care towards you as an employee while you are on placement.

Shared responsibilities – you have a responsibility to learn and act as supernumerary staff. This is an opportunity to join a team and practice some skills. The more you practice, the more your confidence will grow. Always speak to your educator or mentor about the goals you want to achieve and ask them to supervise you.
Communication is key – Talk to your educator or mentor. They can only know what you need if you tell them.
Networking at work – seek out other students. Many units have study days, during this time you will be able to meet other students who you can talk and learn with.

How can you network at work? – be open. 
Introduce yourself to the staff and team and offer your assistance. This may sound daunting, but it is a good way to interact. You may be called on to do interesting tasks.
Look out for any social/sports events and sign up. It’s a great way to meet other people in the company. 
Be open, make eye contact with others, smile at people when you can in the hallway, lift or in the kitchen and say hello. This is actually important - be interested! Make sure you ask open-ended questions
When you finish your placement - reflect on your progress.

components.text: The section provides information that inform you about the placement environment, things you should consider and strategies for coping on placement.

components.title: Happy to help/happy to be here: Identifying components of successful clinical placements for undergraduate nursing students.
Getting the most out of your clinical placement.

components.text: A health or social care placement is a learning environment for skills practice and assessment, but it also provides an opportunity for students to experience work in real time. A lot of students will be excited about this prospect, probably also nervous; many will not know what to expect. The work environment is filled with lots of complexity and uncertainty, particularly in health service delivery. It is however a good chance for you to begin contributing to health care delivery and there will be lots of learning opportunities.
Your feelings about the placement aside, do your best to be prepared for the placement and look forward to a successful placement.

This section will provide some suggestions on what you could do to prepare for placement. Placements can be physically and emotionally exhausting. You need to be prepared for working and the physical and emotional toil working with other people and probably vulnerable people.
Check that you are physically, mentally and emotionally ready for the duration of the placement.

list_elements.text: Have I collected the uniforms and Personal Protective Equipment?
Have I collected my Identity cards?
Have I got my vaccinations? Where to Get?
Have I read the policies and procedures?
Do I understand my legal and statutory duties?
Have I read the Health and Safety policies?
Do I understand the absence policies?
I have collated my placement logbook/ documents
I understand how to complete the logbook/etc.

Have I done a trial journey? – it is good practice to ensure you can get to the placement in good time. You could do a trial run at the time (s) of day you will need to be on duty to ensure you will not be surprised by traffic, parking problems, unexpected child care concerns or other issues.
On time
In a professional manner – be courteous and kind to everyone you meet
Ensure you have a good grasp of the theoretical knowledge you have learned at University
Feel free to ask questions when you are not sure
Get involved in the task and activities, be prepared to learn as much as you can
Show willing interest with a can-do attitude
Do not have your phone on and refrain from checking it constantly
Take responsibility for yourself and your actions, and recognise you are one part of a busy business rather than the focus of it

components.subtitle: Be ready for working in health care

list_elements.text: Plan to care for yourself – eat proper meals, take good rest breaks, sleep, enjoy a regular social life
Take your days off to refresh yourself
Keep fit – physically, emotionally and mentally
Have a contingency plan for isolation – can you meet up regularly with peers, friends and family?

components.subtitle: Your educators will want you to show that

list_elements.text: You are a team player who can work with others
Can manage yourself, take care of your needs, manage emotions
Problem solving
Have the ability to communicate

videos.subtitle: Tips for your first Clinical Placement

components.text: Professional behaviour is usually summarised as a series of actions deemed acceptable in the workplace. Judgements about professional behaviour can be arrived at depending on an individual’s: communicative abilities, critical thinking and problem-solving; initiative and accountability and ethical approaches and reflections. Furthermore, nonverbal gestures and demeanour will also influence how other’s perceive an individual’s professional behaviour.
The following guide is intended to help students, who are preparing for placement, of their responsibilities once they commence placement.
N.b. the Faculty of Health and Life Sciences provides many up-to-date student policies and procedures relating to placement, available at:

links.text: Coventry University - Student Portal - Policies and Procedures

list_elements.text: Students should make every effort to sustain the University's good name and reputation whilst completing their placement. In particular, you should have consideration for your colleagues and your employer’s clients, service users or customers. As you may also come into contact with your employer’s suppliers and other professionals, it is very important your conduct remains consistently professional - at all times.

A student who fails to maintain a reasonable standard of behaviour (deemed by the placement provider according to their disciplinary policy and process), or who compromises their own safety, or the safety of others, may be dismissed from their placement and may face disciplinary procedures through the University’s General Regulations http://www.coventry.ac.uk/cu/registry/regulations .

All placements are subject to the processes of student risk assessment and provider health and safety checks, conducted by Faculty Employability Support. You must however, ensure you have read and understood the documentation in the Student Placement Pack, issued to you by Employability Support at the time of your meeting with the advisor.

During the student risk assessment with the Employability Support advisor, you will have an opportunity to discuss any disabilities or long-term health conditions you are managing. This information will be treated in confidence. If however, the student choses to make a disclosure to the placement provider, the advisor can help you to present this information in a professional way. Doing so, enables the placement provider to make reasonable adjustments, if required. It is the best policy for students to discuss any disabilities or long-term health conditions with the advisor first.
Students must take reasonable care to ensure their actions do not endanger themselves or others around them, and follow any instructions or advice given by staff.
Students must take reasonable care to ensure their actions do not endanger themselves or others around them, and follow any instructions or advice given by staff.

components.text: It goes without saying that your behaviour will have an impact on colleagues and other stakeholders, such as clients and service users. Sometimes students, perhaps through lack of experience, do not recognise that their actions and behaviour may have unintended and long-lasting consequences. As part of your professional development you should take responsibility to regularly reflect upon and modify your actions and behaviour. This is quite normal and part of your development. It is something you can talk to your placement supervisor about. You can also discuss this with the Academic Placement Supervisor allocated to you.
The following guidelines, are consistent with professional standards and behaviours; we would reasonably expect Coventry University students to adhere to these whilst on placement:

list_elements.text: Attend employer briefings/inductions sessions.

Follow employer’s procedures and comply with employer’s statutory and legal requirements relating to,  for example, data protection, children’s  and vulnerable adults safeguarding, food hygiene, health and safety, manual handling, COSH and  the correct use and management of substances hazardous to health (e.g. cleaning products) etc.
Maintain highest standards of professional behaviour and conduct yourself in a mature, responsible, courteous and respectful manner with colleagues, customers, clients and suppliers.

Treat company or organisational information and/or trade secrets, as CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION. During placement you may learn about information relating to the company, a group of companies, or one of their clients. You must not at any time during or after the placement disclose or make use of your knowledge about this confidential information.

Adhere to employers policies, in particular those pertaining to ITS (IT Services) and the use of social networking sites, such as Facebook, Twitter and the internet. If in doubt, do NOT use ICT/ social media for personal purposes, on placement.
Maintain a high standard of customer service and ensure the highest standards of quality are achieved in all duties carried out.
Maintain a high standard of personal hygiene & personal appearance
Attend staff meetings, as well as internal and external training as required, and participate fully in staff development activities.
Work closely with colleagues/supervisors with regard to ensuring that appropriate levels of service are maintained.
In line with employer procedures, during sickness/other absences, ensure your employer placement supervisor and your Academic Placement Supervisor is notified immediately and kept updated.
Seek clarification if you do not understand something or are unsure about what to do, and are worried about the consequences

Under no circumstances should you attend placement under the influence of alcohol or drugs, as this will impair your judgement and expose you and others to risk. This is a serious matter referred to as gross misconduct, so can lead to summary dismissal or termination of placement.

components.subtitle: From The University’s Employability Support Team

list_elements.text: I have sufficient support strategies in place.
I have the contact number of my visiting tutor/Uni contact.
I know my shift patterns and times.
I know when the placement will start and finish.
I have organised care for my children or dependents.
I know when my study days are?
I have organised travel – tickets, parking, permits, note (Limited parking in many hospitals) Tried and tested route.
I am ready to set my goals with my educator/mentor.
I have my placement log.
Is it possible to contact students on the same placement?
I am confident I can have a successful placement.

components.subtitle: Reflection
components.text: Download the document below and complete it as part of your reflection process. This will help you gain confidence and maybe remember things you may have omitted in your preparation.

Students who have frequent severe panic attacks and extreme anxieties may not be keeping track of when these occurrences happen, and may not be aware of why they are more frequently occurring. The following tool can be attached within the online ‘self-guide’ to be downloaded and printed off to be completed. 
It aims to identify the areas in which the student feels comfortable in their placement:

list_elements.text: ‘the comfort zone’
areas they are willing to stretch themselves to be comfortable in e.g. to ask questions more frequently to colleagues aka ‘the stretch zone’
Areas upon which they do not, in this moment in time, feel comfortable engaging in, ‘the fear/panic zone’ e.g. independently dealing with a patient during placement scenario.

components.text: Among students who have a disability and who are embarking on a placement for their course may have increased anxiety levels and these at times can be overwhelming. This tool aims to provide the student a visual aid in which areas they should stretch themselves in, in order to be successful without stressing themselves out too much, and in which areas to avoid to prolong their enjoyment of their placement by not engaging in situations that would be upsetting or potentially damaging to their mental wellbeing/academic achievement. This tool, once completed, may be beneficial for the student to show to their supervisor whilst on placement, so the advisor ensured the student was not forced into doing something that would be detrimental to their mental health, or to provide more support whilst the student is partaking in the task.

components.text: This section presents guidance and suggestions aimed at supporting your learning on placement.
This section will provide you with information and materials about teaching and learning.

Learning happens every day. All the skills and knowledge we use we have learned, however we often take it for granted. There are different learning styles, most people use a combination of learning styles to facilitate their learning.

list_elements.text: Find out which learning styles best facilitate your learning. You can reflect on the things you learn and how your learning was enhanced – it may be the reading material or the way the educator or mentor explained something in particular or even the way you chose to link the theory with the practical skill. Learning how you learn will support your capacity to learn.
Practice, practice, practice! The best way to know if you can do something is to practice – be hands on and develop the confidence to try.

Stay focused and motivated. A healthy diet influences your mood and motivation. Eating plenty of fruits and vegetables, exercising regularly and sleeping well will be particularly useful to ensure you have a good mood and motivation to learn.

Ask for help if you need it. Feel free to say when you do not understand and discuss your scope of practice with your educator and mentor. The educator or mentor will seek to challenge you. This is good for your learning but only you will know if the challenge is inspiring or burdensome.
Self-learn. It is your responsibility to direct your own learning. Focus on learning and it is likely you learn the more.

Develop good relationships with your mentors and educators. You cannot make anyone like you, but being polite and respectful shows you are putting in the effort and most people mimic behaviour when relationships are being developed.
Reflection is good practice. You may want to keep a learning diary where you summarise your experiences and summarise the things you have learned every day.
You never really fail, you just learn differently. Be determined to get better if your performance is below par.

components.subtitle: Tips for learning effectively in practice
Be SMART. Set small, measurable, achievable, realistic goals every week.

list_elements.text: Specific  - a vague goal which is ill defined is less likely to be achieved
Measurable - how will you measure your success,eg 'I will review 5 patients daily on average by the end of the wekk' versus 'I will review more patients by the end of the week'
Achievable - the goal you set should be challenging but not beyond your scope
Relevant - is the goal relevant to your practice? Is this the right time to set this goal? Do I have other goals I need to prioritise first?

Timely - setting a time limit or end point makes the goal focused and easier to achieve. Eg: 'I will review 5 patients daily on average by the end of the week' versus ' I will review 5 patients daily on average'

links.tag: Tips for developing confidence at work
links.text: Crowe Associates - Tip for developing confidence

components.text: Communication is essential when you are on placement. Be honest and transparent with your educator. Provide them with feedback about your learning and how they can best support you in maximising your strengths and developing your weak areas. Be honest with your self – reflect on your progress and be honest about how you can make the most of the placement. See challenges as opportunities to develop and grow. Develop a polite, professional manner when speaking with patients and colleagues.

links.text: Seven reasons to say what is on your mind – be polite and listen actively

components.text: We always try to encourage students to reflect on their feelings and their overall situation. It is an important skill which brings to light issues that then the student can take further steps to solve. In order to do that, we motivate you to read the articles and watch the videos that we consider are very relevant to opening your eyes when it comes to reflection.
