components.subtitle: Communicate with yourself – reflect
components.text: Various models of reflection are available, there is no “right model”. Students are encouraged to use a model that is right for them, one that they feel comfortable with. So many of the models use similar language and activities. Reflective models are used to deconstruct events and consolidate learning.
Make sure you:

list_elements.text: Regularly complete placement log
Compile evidence of learning
Get ready for your half-way meeting
Be self-aware – Take self-assessment

components.text: Be proactive, and demonstrate that you can be an autonomous and hands-on colleague. Always check to ensure your practice is safe and give your educator regular feedback. Show leadership and courage.

links.text: How Good Are Your Leadership Skills?
Effective time management - University of Lincoln (Sway)

components.text: Your health is important. If you are not healthy, you will be unable to learn effectively and you may not be able to perform at optimum levels.

list_elements.text: Eat regular meals.
Exercise
Take regular breaks at the appropriate times
Watch that your sleep patterns are healthy, even though you may have to adjust to night shifts or odd shift patterns
Socialise, do your best to stay socially active and do not lose links with friends or family because you are on placement
Take a break if you need it
Contact your tutor or the disability team if you need support

components.text:
Placements can be a great opportunity to reorganise your finances. You could improve your own financial intelligence. 
Consider what your income may be – what will you earn? Have you saved for placement?
Consider your outgoings – you may need money for accommodation, transportation, utility.

sections.subtitle: Be proactive – take responsibility for learning

components.text: The placement is for you. Go for it!
You can review your RA and have a discussion with your educator/mentor about how well they are helping you.

If you think your RA are not adequate, have a conversation with the Learning Support Tutor about why you will want to change some things. Then talk to your mentor or educator about the changes. Consider how the RA can be introduced. Some RA may not be accessible in particular environments.

Everyone is an individual with unique characteristics, strengths and needs. People may not fully understand your individual needs however you know you best. You can explain your feelings and difficulties experienced to your practice educator as many times as you need.  If you need more support, re-explain your issues with your practice educator. You can also contact the disabilities team and placement team at university for support and ideas.

list_elements.text: Ensure you collate evidence for competencies
Be aware of what you have achieved
Be aware of learning opportunities you need
If relevant – are you ready for end of placement exam/review?
Find opportunities to practice?

Return any equipment and other resources you may have being loaned from the placement site

You may have had a discussion with your educator and visiting tutor or other University staff about how successful the placement experience was. You could also think about going through your notes, diaries or reflection. Articulate your thoughts and learning. This will be useful as you prepare for next placement.

components.subtitle: Did Reasonable Adjustments work well for you?
components.text: Did you have reasonable adjustments, were they suitable? Think about how you could use them on the next placement.

It is good practice for students to reflect on their practice and how the placement went. Some lecturers will encourage students to write a reflective piece about their placement. The University’s Employability Support Team has guidelines.

What follows will be extracts from the linked document below, giving you guidelines on what reflective writing is and how to write it. If you want to read the entire document, download the document from the link below. The extracts represent the parts that are relevant to reflective writing, but the document contains other relevant information as well.

links.link: pdfs/Guidelines for Academics Supervising Sandwich Placement Students_Sept 2017.docx
links.text: Guidelines for Academics Supervising Sandwich Placement (Pages 18-21)

components.text:
Reflection is an everyday process. We all reflect on a range of everyday problems and situations all the time: What went well? What didn’t? Why?
How do I feel about it?

We don’t usually follow a formula for this - it just happens as feelings, thoughts and emotions about something gradually ‘surfacing’. We might choose to do something differently, or not, as a result of reflecting, but reflection is essentially a kind of loose processing of thoughts and feelings about an incident, a meeting, a day – any event or experience at all.

Reflection can be a more structured way of processing in order to deal with a problem. This type of reflection may take place when we have had time to stand back from something, or talk it through, as in: ‘On reflection, I think you might be right’, or ‘On second thoughts, I realised he was more upset than me.’

This might take a more structured form, if we consciously reflect (e.g. a teacher reflecting on a lesson). In this kind of reflection, the aim is to think carefully about what happened, sort out what is really going on and explore in depth, with a view to change or improvement in the future.

sections.subtitle: The Nature and Content of Reflection

components.text: ‘… a form of mental processing with a purpose and/or anticipated outcome that is applied to relatively complex or unstructured ideas for which there is not an obvious solution'
components.author: Moon

components.text: She continues by outlining some of the purposes for reflection:

list_elements.text: To consider the process of our own learning – a process of metacognition
To critically review something - our own behaviour, that of others or the product of behaviour (e.g. an essay, book, painting etc.)
To build theory from observations: we draw theory from generalisations - sometimes impractical situations, sometimes in thoughts or a mixture of the two
To engage in personal or self-development
To make decisions or resolve uncertainty

components.text: Reflection is a type of thinking associated with deep thought, aimed at achieving better understanding. It contains a mixture of elements:

list_elements.text: We don’t always learn from experiences. Reflection is where we analyse experience, actively attempting to ‘make sense’ or find the meaning in it.
It can be hard to reflect when we are caught up in an activity. ‘Standing back’ gives a better view or perspective on an experience, issue or action.
Reflection involves ‘going over’ something, often several times, in order to get a broad view and check nothing is missed
Reflection is associated with ‘striving after truth’. Through reflection, we can acknowledge things that we find difficult to admit in the normal course of events.
Reflection involves being even-handed, or balanced in judgement. This means taking everything into account, not just the most obvious.
Reflection can bring greater clarity, like seeing events reflected in a mirror. This can help at any stage of planning, carrying out and reviewing activities.
Reflection is about learning and understanding on a deeper level. This includes gaining valuable insights that cannot be just ‘taught’.
Reflection involves an element of drawing conclusions in order to move on, change or develop an approach, strategy or activity.

components.text: Reflective writing is evidence of reflective thinking. In an academic context, reflective thinking usually involves:

list_elements.text: Looking back at something (often an event, i.e. something that happened, but it could also be an idea or object).
Analysing the event or idea (thinking in depth and from different perspectives, and trying to explain, often with reference to a model or theory from your subject).
Thinking carefully about what the event or idea means for you and your on-going progress as a learner and/or practising professional.

components.text: Reflective writing is thus more personal than other kinds of academic writing. We all think reflectively in everyday life, of course, but perhaps not to the same depth as that expected in good reflective writing at university level.

components.subtitle: Example of reflective writing
components.text:
Specific tasks were shared out amongst members of my team. Initially, however, the tasks were not seen as equally difficult by all team members. Cooperation between group members was at risk because of this perception of unfairness. Social interdependence theory recognises a type of group interaction called ‘positive interdependence’, meaning cooperation (Johnson &
Johnson, 1993, cited by Maughan & Webb, 2001), and many studies have demonstrated that “cooperative learning experiences encourage higher achievement” (Maughan & Webb, 2001).  Ultimately, our group achieved a successful outcome, but to improve the process, we perhaps needed a chairperson to help encourage cooperation when tasks were being shared out. In future group work, on the course and at work, I would probably suggest this.

links.text: Maughan, C., & Webb, J. (2001). Small group learning and assessment.  Retrieved 01/10/11 from the Higher Education Academy website

sections.subtitle: What is involved? The process of reflective writing

list_elements.text: Description – what happened?
Interpretation – What is most important/relevant/useful about the event? How can it be explained (through reference to a theoretical framework)?
Outcome – What have I learned from this? What does this mean for my future?
Description – what happened?
Feelings and Analysis – how did it go? Why? How did you feel about it? What was behind your feelings and actions?
Theory – What was really going on? What needs to be looked at again, done differently next time?
Action – What should be done next time? How?

components.text: Reflection is an exploration and an explanation of events – not just a description of them.

There is a vast literature on ‘reflective practice’.  A number of explanatory frameworks have been devise, in order to depict and explain the cognitive and affective processed involved. One of the most widely used is that of Gibbs (1988).

components.subtitle: Questions to consider at each step of the Gibbs cycle

list_elements.text: What happened? Give a concise, factual account.  Provide relevant details.

components.subtitle: Feelings
components.text:
Identify and examine reactions, feelings and thoughts at the time.
It is important, although often difficult, to be honest about these.

list_elements.text: How can you explain your feelings? What was affecting them? Did they change? Why?
How did they affect your actions and thoughts at the time?
Looking back, have your views on this changed?

components.subtitle: Evaluation
components.text: Look at the judgements you made at the time about how things were going.

list_elements.text: What was positive? Negative? What made you think this?
Try to stand back from the experience to gain a sense of how it went.
What made you think something was good or bad?
Examine your own judgements and what contributed to them. How do you feel about them now?

components.subtitle: Analysis
components.text: In this section of the reflection, you need to examine the experience in depth, and start to theorise about key aspects. Try to identify an overarching issue, or key aspect of the experience that affected it profoundly, which needs to be examined for the future. For example, an aspect of communication or time management might have played a central part in the outcome.

list_elements.text: How was it flawed this time? In what way? Why? How should it work in this situation?
What ideas or theories are you aware of which look at this? Does theory about this aspect help you make more sense of what happened?

Could you use theory to improve this aspect in the future? In this section, you need to fully examine and make sense of factors affecting the situation, and exploring ways to change and develop these.

components.subtitle: Conclusion
components.text: Sum up the key things learned through the reflective process, the main factors affecting the situation, and what needs to be improved. This section might include identifying specific skills that need developing. You might identify new knowledge or training which is needed.

components.subtitle: Action plan
components.text: This should be a practical section:

list_elements.text: What could you do differently next time and how could you prepare for this?
What areas need developing or planning? What resources do you need, and where would they be found?
What steps will be taken first?

components.text: A very useful and detailed discussion of each stage of the Gibbs model can be found in:
For additional reading about reflection:

components.title: Learning by Doing. A Guide to Teaching and Learning Methods.
Learning Journals: A handbook for academics, students and professional development.

components.text: Evaluating a placement is useful for many reasons. It helps you celebrate your success and reflect on the things that went well and any things that could have gone better. You can use this experience to prepare for your next placement. There are forms you could complete that enable the placement teams collate your experiences and used by the teams to improve placement training and processes.
